trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomised phase III study to evaluate whether a lower versus a higher oxygen saturation target in infants of <28 weeks gestation is associated with a reduction in death or disability at 2 years of age.

conditions.healthcondition: The role of oxygen saturation targetting in morbidity and mortality in infants born less than 28 weeks gestation

interventions.interventions: Infants are randomised at less than 24 hours of age to an oxygen saturation target of 85%-89% or 91%-95%.
interventions.comparator: Control group is oxygen saturation target of 91%-95%

primaryOutcome.timepoint: At 2 years of age corrected for gestation at birth

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Severe retinopathy of prematurity subjected to retinal surgery - eyes assessed by indirect ophthalmoscopy and treatment given when Type 1 disease identified
Growth: Weight, length and head circumference at birth, hospital discharge and 2 years of age
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At 2 years old corrected for gestation at birth

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Cerebral palsy as assesed by paediatric examination
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At 2 years old corrected for gestation at birth
At 2 years of age corrected for gestation at birth

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Duration of use of positive airway respiratory support - endotracheal ventilation or nasal CPAP.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At 2 years of age corrected for gestation at birth

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Mean Bayley III developmental assessment cognitive score
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At 2 years of age corrected for gestational age

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Re-admissions to hospital before 24 months of age corrected for gestation
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At 2 years of age corrected for gestation
At 2 years of age corrected for gestation

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Less than 28 weeks gestation; less than 24 hours of age; signed parental consent.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Congenital anomaly affecting oxygenation; clearly will be unable to follow up.

trial_design.sequence: Stratified by hospital; less than 26 weeks gestation ot 26 weeks gestation or more with allocation by computer programme..

fundingsource.fundingname: Health Research Council of New Zealand
fundingsource.fundingaddress: PO Box 5541, Wellesley Street, Auckland 1141, New Zealand

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Oxygen is the commonest neonatal therapy. Unfortunately, both too much and too little oxygen may be harmful for very premature infants. We now measure the oxygen in a baby's blood by oxygen saturation but the optimum range in the first few weeks is unknown and no randomised controlled trial (RCT) has addressed this question. This proposal is for a New Zealand arm of a major international study involving 5000 babies, born at less than 28 weeks, to address this question. Babies will be randomised to a higher or lower target range of oxygen saturation from birth (85-89% or 91-95%). For all oximeters staff will target a masked range of 88-92%. We will assess which of the two target ranges is associated with the best overall outcome, which is a composite measure of survival, disability on a standard test of neurodevelopment (Bayley scales), and visual function at 2 years of age.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: Multi-region Ethics Committee of the NZ Ministry of Health
